title: Two objects. Same room. Two different temperatures?

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the metal hard drive and the book in terms of their temperature, even though they are the same temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: The book is warmer than the hard drive because it has more knowledge.

options.label: B
options.text: The hard drive is warmer than the book because it has a higher temperature reading.

options.label: C
options.text: The hard drive feels colder than the book because it conducts heat away from your hand faster.

options.label: D
options.text: The book is colder than the hard drive because it has a lower temperature reading.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason why the aluminium block feels colder than the plastic block, even though they are the same temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: The aluminium block has a higher temperature reading than the plastic block.

options.label: B
options.text: The aluminium block is a worse thermoconductor than the plastic block.

options.label: C
options.text: The aluminium block is a better conductor of heat than the plastic block.

options.label: D
options.text: The plastic block has a higher temperature reading than the aluminium block.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the ice cube melt more quickly on the aluminium block than on the plastic block?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the aluminium block is a worse conductor of heat than the plastic block.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the plastic block is a better conductor of heat than the aluminium block.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the aluminium block conducts heat away from the ice cube faster than the plastic block.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the ice cube is in direct contact with the aluminium block.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that explains why the aluminium block conducts heat away from your hand faster than the book?

options.label: A
options.text: Thermoconductivity

options.label: B
options.text: Heat transfer

options.label: C
options.text: Thermal conductivity

options.label: D
options.text: Conduction

multiple-choice.question: Why does the bath mat feel nicer to stand on than a towel in winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the bath mat is warmer than the towel.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the bath mat conducts heat away from your hand faster than the towel.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the towel has a higher temperature reading than the bath mat.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the bath mat has a lower temperature reading than the towel.

multiple-choice.question: C: The hard drive feels colder than the book because it conducts heat away from your hand faster.
C: The aluminium block is a better conductor of heat than the plastic block.
C: Because the aluminium block conducts heat away from the ice cube faster than the plastic block.
A: Thermoconductivity
B: Because the bath mat conducts heat less quickly away from you.

title: Can You Solve This?

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker propose to gather information to figure out the rule of the sequence?

options.label: A
options.text: By proposing a set of numbers that follow the rule and then asking for confirmation.

options.label: B
options.text: By proposing a set of numbers that do not follow the rule and then asking for confirmation.

options.label: C
options.text: By proposing a set of numbers and then trying to disprove the rule.

options.label: D
options.text: D: By simply thinking strategically about the rule.

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's initial expectation of how the audience would approach the problem?

options.label: A
options.text: To think strategically about the rule and propose numbers that fit with that rule.

options.label: B
options.text: To try to disprove the rule by proposing numbers that do not fit with it.

options.label: C
options.text: To simply propose numbers that fit with their initial rule and then confirm it.

options.label: D
options.text: To not think about the problem at all.

multiple-choice.question: What was the actual rule of the sequence that the speaker was looking for?

options.label: A
options.text: To multiply each number by 2.

options.label: B
options.text: To add 2 to each number.

options.label: C
options.text: To multiply each number by 3.

options.label: D
options.text: To propose numbers in increasing order.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to the scientific method?

options.label: A
options.text: To confirm our theories and expect the answer to be yes.

options.label: B
options.text: To disprove our theories and get the no's.

options.label: C
options.text: To think strategically about the rule and propose numbers that fit with it.

options.label: D
options.text: To not think about the problem at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the moral of the story that the speaker is trying to convey?

options.label: A
options.text: That we should always try to confirm our theories and expect the answer to be yes.

options.label: B
options.text: That we should always try to disprove our theories and get the no's.

options.label: C
options.text: That we should never think about the problem at all.

options.label: D
options.text: That we should always think strategically about the rule and propose numbers that fit with it.

options.label: D

options.text: That you were among the largest group of people living in the United States of America.

options.text: That you were one of the original people who lived in the United States of America.

options.label: D
options.text: That you were one of the founding fathers of the United States of America.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A shelter built from mud bricks and clay.

options.label: C
options.text: They were known for their skills in fishing.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of baseballs.

multiple-choice.question: Why was Charles Darwin, the father of evolution theory, so interested in pigeons to support his theory?

options.label: A
options.text: Darwin knew that every country had a form of pigeons.

options.label: B
options.text: Darwin knew that despite the differences, pigeons all came from the Rock Dove.

options.label: C
options.text: Darwin was able to examine pigeons more easily than other animals.

options.label: D
options.text: Darwin thought the fancy pigeons would attract more attention than armadillos.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It allows them to magnify their focus on objects.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows them to remember things humans can't.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows them to see things humans can't.

options.label: D
options.text: He trained them to crack enemy messages.

title: Why do we pass gas? - Purna Kashyap

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of gas in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: Ingestion of air during sleep

options.label: B
options.text: Bacteria in the intestines as they digest parts of food

options.label: C
options.text: Undigested food that comes to the large intestine

options.label: D
options.text: Volatile sulfur compounds

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of the bacteria in the intestine?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down proteins and fats

options.label: B
options.text: To make vitamins and boost the immune system

options.label: C
options.text: To produce methane and other gases

options.label: D
options.text: To digest complex carbohydrates

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: High amounts of fats and oils

options.label: D
options.text: High amounts of sugars and starches

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They start to produce less gas

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To counterbalance the force created by a single gondolier

options.label: D
options.text: To attach the oar from the water

options.text: To make the gondola more maneuverable

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To counterbalance the force created by a single gondolier

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a benefit of globalization?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced economic growth and increased poverty

options.label: B
options.text: Increased economic growth and improved living standards

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased international trade and reduced economic cooperation

options.label: D
options.text: No impact on economic growth and living standards

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the movement of goods, services, and capital across international borders?

options.label: A
options.text: International trade

options.label: B
options.text: Globalization

options.label: C
options.text: Globalization

options.label: D
options.text: Economic integration

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a free market economy?

options.label: A
options.text: Government control over the economy

options.label: B
options.text: Limited economic freedom and high government intervention

options.label: C
options.text: Free market forces determine the prices and output of goods and services

options.label: D
options.text: Government regulation of prices and output

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the economic system in which a country's government plays a significant role in guiding the economy?

options.label: A
options.text: Market economy

options.label: B
options.text: Command economy

options.label: C
options.text: Mixed economy

options.label: D
options.text: Socialism

title: What if the Earth stopped spinning?

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if the Earth suddenly stopped spinning?

options.label: A
options.text: The atmosphere would slowly leak into space.

options.label: B
options.text: The oceans would surge onto land in tsunamis kilometers high.

options.label: C
options.text: The Sun would seem to freeze in the sky as days became 365 days long.

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth's magnetic field would become stronger.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we feel the Earth's rotation?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Earth's rotation is too sudden.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the Earth is too small.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the change in velocity is too gradual.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Earth's rotation is too slow.

multiple-choice.question: What is the definition of a second in terms of atomic physics?

options.label: A
options.text: The time it takes for the Earth to complete one rotation.

options.label: B
options.text: The time it takes for the Moon to orbit the Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of oscillations between two levels of an atom of cesium 133.

options.label: D
options.text: The time it takes for the Sun to complete one rotation.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it necessary to adjust the time used in GPS systems?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Earth's rotation is too slow.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the Earth's rotation is too fast.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the Earth's rotation is slowing down over time.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Earth's rotation is speeding up over time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the system used to keep the pace of seconds accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: TAI time.

options.label: B
options.text: UTC time.

options.label: C
options.text: Earth's rotation time.

options.label: D
options.text: Atomic clock time.

title: Why does the sun really shine?

multiple-choice.question: Their eyeballs are a major component of their skulls. On the video, they gave a comparison if humans had pigeon-like eyeballs. How big would the human eyeballs be?

options.label: A
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of tomatoes.

options.label: B
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of watermelons.

options.label: C
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of grapefruits.

options.label: D
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of baseballs.

multiple-choice.question: Why was Charles Darwin, the father of evolution theory, so interested in pigeons to support his theory?

options.label: A
options.text: Darwin knew that every country had a form of pigeons.

options.label: B
options.text: Darwin knew that despite the differences, pigeons all came from the Rock Dove.

options.label: C
options.text: Darwin was able to examine pigeons more easily than other animals.

options.label: D
options.text: Darwin thought the fancy pigeons would attract more attention than armadillos.

multiple-choice.question: What is the size of a pigeon's brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The size of your thumb

options.label: B
options.text: The size of a fingertip

options.label: C
options.text: The size of a walnut

options.label: D
options.text: The size of a golf ball

multiple-choice.question: What do pigeons' "super eyes" allow them to do?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to be more balanced and agile than humans.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows them to magnify their focus on objects.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows them to remember things humans can't.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows them to see things humans can't.

multiple-choice.question: Why did B.F. Skinner try and train pigeons during World War II?

options.label: A
options.text: He trained them to help crash enemy planes.

options.label: B
options.text: He trained them to deliver messages.

options.label: C
options.text: He trained them in order to make them aerial bombers.

options.label: D
options.text: He trained them to crack enemy messages.

title: What happens when you remove the hippocampus? - Sam Kean

multiple-choice.question: What type of surgery did Dr. William Scoville perform on Henry Molaison (H.M.) in 1953?

options.label: A
options.text: A partial lobotomy to treat mental patients

options.label: B
options.text: A brain transplant to replace a damaged part of the brain

options.label: C
options.text: A removal of H.M.'s hippocampus to treat seizures

options.label: D
options.text: A spinal cord surgery to treat paralysis

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary problem that H.M. experienced after the surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: He experienced increased seizures

options.label: B
options.text: He lost most of his memories from the previous decade and was unable to form new ones

options.label: C
options.text: He became more aggressive and violent

options.label: D
options.text: He developed a speech impediment

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the key findings of Brenda Milner's research on H.M.?

options.label: A
options.text: H.M. was able to form new memories, but forgot them immediately

options.label: B
options.text: H.M. retained information long enough to finish a sentence or find the bathroom, but forgot it shortly after

options.label: C
options.text: H.M. was able to recall memories from his childhood, but not from his adult life

options.label: D
options.text: H.M. was able to learn new skills, but not remember them

multiple-choice.question: What is the distinction between short-term and long-term memory, according to Brenda Milner's research?

options.label: A
options.text: Short-term memory is the ability to recall information from the past decade, while long-term memory is the ability to recall information from before that

options.label: B
options.text: Short-term memory is the ability to recall information for a few minutes, while long-term memory is the ability to recall information for a longer period of time

options.label: C
options.text: Short-term memory is the ability to recall information that is not stored in the hippocampus, while long-term memory is the ability to recall information that is stored in the hippocampus

options.label: D
options.text: Short-term memory is the ability to recall information that is not stored in the cortex, while long-term memory is the ability to recall information that is stored in the cortex

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of H.M.'s brain being preserved and scanned after his death?

options.label: A
options.text: It allowed neuroscientists to study the brain's structure and function in greater detail

options.label: B
options.text: It allowed researchers to develop new treatments for memory disorders

options.label: C
options.text: It allowed scientists to understand the neural basis of memory and how it is stored in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: It allowed researchers to develop new techniques for brain surgery

title: Feedback loops: How nature gets its rhythms - Anje-Margriet Neutel

multiple-choice.question: What is the key element that makes feedback beneficial in the natural world?

options.label: A
options.text: Mutual causal interaction

options.label: B
options.text: Positive feedback

options.label: C
options.text: Negative feedback

options.label: D
options.text: Amplifying loops

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of positive feedback in ecosystems?

options.label: A
options.text: When plants grow and die, leaving less organic matter and nutrients for other plants to grow

options.label: B
options.text: When removing a forest makes it vulnerable to erosion

options.label: C
options.text: When predators and their prey maintain a long-term equilibrium

options.label: D
options.text: When spraying pesticides helps plants grow by killing pest insects

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a negative link is added to a feedback loop?

options.label: A
options.text: The feedback force becomes stronger

options.label: B
options.text: The feedback force remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: The feedback force becomes weaker

options.label: D
options.text: The feedback force is reversed entirely

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a food web containing many feedback loops?

options.label: A
options.text: A forest ecosystem with only two species

options.label: B
options.text: A desert ecosystem with a single species

options.label: C
options.text: A tropical rainforest with many species and strong feedbacks among living and dead matter

options.label: D
options.text: A single species living in isolation

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a desert ecosystem with weak feedback loops and slow biomass turnover?

options.label: A
options.text: It is characterized by many oscillations and a powerful sound

options.label: B
options.text: It is like a constant drone

options.label: C
options.text: It is like a lush panoply of sounds

options.label: D
options.text: It is a stable and harmonious ecosystem

title: What can Schrödinger's cat teach us about quantum mechanics? - Josh Samani

multiple-choice.question: What type of physics governs the behavior of systems at small scales, such as atoms, and is different from the physics of everyday macroscopic objects?

options.label: A
options.text: Classical mechanics

options.label: B
options.text: Quantum mechanics

options.label: C
options.text: Relativity

options.label: D
options.text: Thermodynamics

multiple-choice.question: According to the thought experiment of Schrödinger's cat, what state is the cat in before the box is opened?

options.label: A
options.text: Alive

options.label: B
options.text: Dead

options.label: C
options.text: In a superposition state, both alive and dead

options.label: D
options.text: Undetermined

options.label: A
options.text: Quantum entanglement

options.label: B
options.text: Quantum superposition

options.label: C
options.text: Quantum decoherence

options.label: D
options.text: Quantum measurement

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the experiment with two entangled cats, where one cat is alive and the other is dead, even when the boxes are moved to opposite ends of the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: Both cats are alive

options.label: B
options.text: Both cats are dead

options.label: C
options.text: One cat is alive and the other is dead

options.label: D
options.text: The outcome is undetermined

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Quantum mechanics

options.label: C
options.text: Quantum physics

options.label: D
options.text: Quantum engineering

title: Should I stay or should I switch doors?

What is the strategy that the game show host Monty Hall recommends to the contestant in order to increase their chances of winning?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Switch to the other unopened door

options.text: Open one of the doors to see what's behind it

title: The past, present and future of the bubonic plague - Sharon N. DeWitte

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the world's population was destroyed by the Black Death?
What was the primary cause of the Black Death's rapid spread in the 14th century?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: The same bacterium that causes bubonic plague today

options.label: C
options.text: Direct communication from one person to another

options.text: The Plague of Justinian in 541 CE

options.label: D

title: How optical illusions trick your brain - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What causes the white intersections in the grid to appear differently in the peripheral vision?

options.label: A
options.text: Flashes of grey added to the animation

options.label: B
options.text: A defect in the printed paper

options.label: C
options.text: More white around the intersections due to lateral inhibition

options.label: D
options.text: A problem with the lighting of the image

multiple-choice.question: What assumption does the brain's visual cortex make about the lighting of an image?

options.label: A
options.text: Light comes from a single source, shining down from the side

options.label: B
options.text: Light comes from a single source, shining down from above

options.label: C
options.text: Light comes from multiple sources, shining down from all directions

options.label: D
options.text: Light comes from a single source, shining up from below

options.text: The occipital lobe

options.label: B
options.text: The temporal lobe

options.label: C
options.text: The fusiform face area

multiple-choice.question: Why do optical illusions trick us into seeing 3D shapes in 2D images?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the images are drawn incorrectly

options.label: B
options.text: Because the images are too small

options.label: C
options.text: Because our brains are using assumptions about visual information to create a tailored, edited vision of the world

options.label: D
options.text: Because our brains are lazy and not paying attention

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of lateral inhibition in the retinal ganglion cells?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase contrast with adjacent white spots

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease contrast with adjacent white spots

options.label: C
options.text: To increase contrast with adjacent black spots

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease contrast with adjacent black spots

title: The secret lives of baby fish - Amy McDermott

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the Earth's surface do coral reefs make up?
What is the primary way that fertilized eggs are dispersed in the water column?

options.label: A
options.text: By being swept away by ocean currents

options.label: B
options.text: By being carried by ocean currents and riding the right currents to find their way to a suitable adult habitat

options.label: C
options.text: By being actively swum to a suitable adult habitat

options.label: D
options.text: By being absorbed by adult fish

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the ways that larvae navigate to their eventual homes?

options.label: A
options.text: By using only their sense of smell

options.label: B
options.text: By using only their sense of hearing

options.label: C
options.text: By using a complex suite of sensory systems, detecting both sound and smell

options.label: D
options.text: By using a magnetic compass

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process by which larvae drop down in the water column to check out a reef below, and then jump back up if conditions aren't right?

options.label: A
options.text: Bungee system

options.label: B
options.text: Drifting behavior

options.label: C
options.text: Settling behavior

options.label: D
options.text: Migration pattern

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the things that scientists do not yet know about the geographic movements of individual larvae?

options.label: A
options.text: Which exact environmental cues and behaviors they use to navigate to the reefs they will call home

options.label: B
options.text: The geographic movements of individual larvae for most species

options.label: C
options.text: Which reefs are the most suitable for each species

options.label: D
options.text: How larvae are able to detect the presence of predators
